subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... No. It shows the Shavian and Quikscript repertoires. and colours those characters which are in common and unified. ... Alternate forms are, I thought, out
messageBody:
At 22:28 +0000 2007-10-31, amd64_hacker wrote:

>I see two tables which seem to show the same space but have different
>values, is that a typo?

No. It shows the Shavian and Quikscript repertoires. and colours
those characters which are in common and unified.

>I omitted characters with alternate forms (DAY, UTTER and similar) from
>the draft.

Alternate forms are, I thought, out of scope for encoding but a
matter for context in the font..

>For example, UTTER's alternate form looks something like a reverse ROE
>or a Shavian LOLL, I think that makes it unsuitable for merging.

A Quikscript font will behave much differently from a Shavian font.
Shavian fonts have no shaping behaviour (since the ligatures are all
explicitly encoded).

>DAY/DEAD, I'm fairly certain, has the same alternate form in Shavian and
>QuikScript.

Shavian has alternate forms? Not in any font I have seen.

>The glyphs for AH, AWE and MIME, NUN are identical, but the sounds are
>not alike.

What is your point? Currently I have been generous in encoding,
though formally these might be unifiable.

>What happens script wise if we merge Shavian and QuikScript?
>I presume a new Unicode block will be created for the 'QuikScript
>Extentions',

"Shavian Quikscript Extensions".

> but do we inherit the script code Shaw or do we get a new one?

You would inherit the script code Shaw... though possibly a Shaq
variant might make sense.
--
Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com
